ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning to situate text and authors in their respective contexts, and deeply engage with their material
A really thorough understanding and line of thought into a canon of important texts the interaction between the colonized and the colonizer.

I had never written a paper longer than 12 pages before taking this class, so the 20 page paper was definitely a challenge and didn't turn out perfectly. However, I definitely learned about planning and researching such a long piece as well as learned a great deal about my topic.
Many English courses discourage evaluating the material in terms of the historical/cultural background and the author's psyche, so this was a welcome change.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: An excellent course that focused on a diversity of writers

Strengths: an incredible, insightful Professor who understands the texts on the level of craft as well as analysis Weaknesses: Because we only met once a week, it didn't feel like we were grappling with the material as a group as a much as we could.

I don't really have a solution for this, but it was difficult to pick a topic for the final paper before we had gone through the course's reading list. It definitely felt like crunch time between submitting the proposal and finishing the paper, but I'm not sure how the course could be restructured to give us more time. It would at least have been helpful to have the paper due at the end of finals rather than at the end of reading period.

Not really sure how to answer this question. It is a pretty standard seminar course, so it tends to be more flexible. Prof. Phillips was pretty good at directing the conversation without resorting to lecturing. Small class size was also very beneficial.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they're interested in the topic being taught

Yes if you are interested in reading the texts on the syllabus, there is no one more informed and invested in the themes and craft of post-colonial writing from Conrad to Ondaaje as much as Caryl Phillips. He personally knows these guys.
Absolutely. Professor Phillis is charming,clever, isnightful and open, and the class is almost entirely based on your interactions with him. It is a pleasure to get to do so.
Yes. Definitely a seminar designed for English majors. Plan for the 20-25 page paper accordingly.
